title: 113_s1126
content: The "Prescribe A Book Act" establishes Pediatric Early Literacy Programs under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. It includes definitions for pediatric involvement in reading and education. The "Prescribe A Book Act" defines an eligible entity as a nonprofit organization with demonstrated effectiveness in peer-to-peer training for healthcare providers in literacy promotion, delivering training curriculum in various medical education settings, providing technical assistance for Pediatric Early Literacy Programs, and offering opportunities for local healthcare facilities. The "Prescribe A Book Act" offers discounts for local healthcare facilities to obtain books and integrates developmental research into training for healthcare providers. The Pediatric Early Literacy Program promotes early language and literacy through a 3-part model implemented by trained healthcare providers. The "Prescribe A Book Act" promotes early literacy by providing developmentally appropriate books to children, offering recommendations to parents, and encouraging reading aloud in healthcare facilities. The "Prescribe A Book Act" promotes early literacy by endorsing developmentally appropriate books for children, encouraging parents to read aloud, and receiving support from medical associations. The "Prescribe A Book Act" authorizes grants for Pediatric Early Literacy Programs. Eligible entities must submit applications and provide matching funds. Grant funds must be used for literacy initiatives. An eligible entity receiving a grant under section 5622 must enter into contracts with private nonprofit organizations or public agencies to establish and operate Pediatric Early Literacy Programs. They must provide training and technical assistance to contractors and include terms determined by the Secretary for program effectiveness. Contractors are selected based on their priority to serve at-risk populations. The grant program gives priority to serving at-risk children, including those from low-income families, without adequate medical insurance, enrolled in Medicaid or CHIP, living in rural areas, migrant children, and those with limited library access. Eligible entities must arrange book discounts to receive payments, and report annually on program effectiveness. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act is amended to include a new subpart for pediatric early literacy programs, with sections outlining definitions, program authorization, applications, matching requirements, use of grant funds, payment restrictions, and reporting requirements. Eligible entities must prioritize serving at-risk children and report annually on program effectiveness.
